fields.description:
At the moment I'm in the process of testing Bamboo and, as part of that, of deploying a large-ish number of test agents across a number of platforms. Something I have to do every time is to set capabilities like architecture, operating system, operating system release, compilers installed, etc, etc. This capabilities are used then by the test plans to find the right agent. This is a tedious and error-prone work that has to be done every time a new agent is created. The agents already do a good work of finding out some capabilities (like JVM version or shells) but I think this should be extended:

1) Including most useful system properties from the agent's JVM, like architecture, OS, etc
2) Including environment variables from the agent's host
3) Including some basic platform specific checks (perhaps "uname -a" if a UNIX, "rpm -qa" if RPM is installed, "cat /etc/*-release" to find out the Linux distribution, etc, etc)
4) Providing a well-know extension point for custom capabilities (what about running by default, if present, something like ${agent.home}/extension/customCapabilities.sh that would return to the agent through stdout a properties stream including any desired custom capabilities).

Please tell me what you think about this.
fields.summary: Increase the number of autodetected agent capabilities (eg, operating system, platform, architecture, etc)

fields.description:
I believe it is set to 5 by default. If a server is shut down for any reason there is a good chance that all remote agents will have to be restarted too. This is extremelly unconvenient, specially for production systems because there can be a large number of remote agents that will need to be manually restarted one by one. I know this can be configured in the agent config files but this goes against one of the nicest features of the agents: that they are almost "zero-conf" as they detect everything about the environment. So I'd suggest either:

a) Set the value much higher by default, so that at least one hour or two hours of server downtime doesn't kill the agents.
b) Or have a way of propagating this value from the server to all agents, so that it can be configured in a single place and the value passed to any new agents.
fields.summary: Default number of server connection retries for remote agents is too low for production systems, in my opinion
If the checkout directory does not contain a hg repository we should delete that directory and clone

There are two work arounds for this:
One is to set in your .hgrc
{noformat}
[format]
usestore = False
{noformat}

But this changes the mercurial repository format from the default one to make it not compatible with other operating systems.

The other is to use the [Win32LongFileNamesExtension|http://mercurial.selenic.com/wiki/Win32LongFileNamesExtension] which does not work with binary releases of Mercurial for Windows.

fields.description:
When the an elastic agent reconfigures log4j, log4j will go and try and load all the classes in the file.  It will also try and load BeanInfo introspection classes, for example, PatternLayoutBeanInfo, that don't exist.  It doesn't matter to log4j that they don't exist, however, if this loading hasn't been cached as a miss already, then the AgentClassLoader tries and loads the class.  It connects to the tunnel server, and waits on the socket for a reply.  Meanwhile, the tunnel server tries to log some stuff.  If the logging level is low enough for that to make it to an appender, then it will encounter a lock taken out by the thread configuring log4j, and waiting on the socket that its serving, and it will block itself, resulting in a deadlock.

Solution is to switch the context classloader to the system classloader before reconfiguring log4j.
fields.summary: Reloading log4j properties can result in deadlock on elastic agents

fields.description:
When we were on Bamboo 2.6.3, each time the build failed with "unable to delete the previous build's directory" error, the developers would receive an email, and the build would complete with "Unknown" status, and an orange icon with a slash in it, and the developer received an email. The dev's were very happy about that.

With an upgrade to 3.0.1 the same event (failed to delete the previous build's directory) is being flagged an an error. Is there a way to configure Bamboo that failure to delete the previous build directory was flagged again as an "unknown" status and developer received an email?
fields.summary: Additional build status for repository errors

fields.description:
Currently, Bamboo sends one email per recipient when sending notifications.

So that the users being notification can discuss the notification, Bamboo should offer an option that would allow a single email to be send to all the recipients (and have all the emails in the notification).

Currently, users receiving the notification, don't know who are the other users being notified.
fields.summary: Allow all the email addresses being notified to be visible in the Plan/Job notification message

fields.description:
There are quite a few managers are not available for injection in plugins. One in particular, {{ChainExecutionManager}} is preventing me from continuing development as I am unable to launch a manual build of a plan. Some of these managers are referenced in the plugin documentation and thusly invalidate examples. Some include:

- ChainExecutionManager
- ChangeDetectionManager
- BuildNumberGeneratorService
- TriggerReasonManager
fields.summary: Managers not injectable into plugins

fields.description:
We tried to use the following jobs with different Subversion locations in a plan in Bamboo:

- *Main job*: https://svn.atlassian.com/svn/private/atlassian/confluence/branches/confluence-project-3.5-stable
- *Plugin trigger job*: https://svn.atlassian.com/svn/public/atlassian/bamboo/plugins/build-trigger-scripts/trunk

Notice that the first job uses {{/svn/private/}} and the second uses {{/svn/public/}} -- different paths on the same host.

Bamboo fails when running the second job because it attempts to check out the first job's revision on the second job's Subversion repository, which does not work:

bq. Failed to checkout source code to revision '148195' ...

Here's an example on our internal Bamboo server:

* https://bamboo.extranet.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSTAB-MAIN-76
fields.summary: Jobs with different Subversion repositories on the same host: "Failed to checkout source code to revision"

fields.description:
When Elastic Bamboo starts an agent, it checks to see if the 'elasticbamboo' security group and key pair exist. If they don't, it creates them and stores the elasticbamboo.pk private key on the file system.

However, if this elasticbamboo.pk file is lost or if this Bamboo is not the first Bamboo to have generated the PK file, it will not save this file again, leaving no way for people to SSH into their elastic instances.
fields.summary: Elastic Bamboo does not save a new elasticbamboo.pk after regenerating a key pair

fields.description:
Build Expiry mostly filters builds based on age. The 'minimum builds to keep' setting additionally allows you to specify a certain threshold beyond which NOT to delete builds. At least that's the way I'm interpreting it. There are situations, however, where some builds may generate a lot of artifacts (say performance builds or builds that generate big artifacts). In any 24 or 48 hour period, I may be firing dozens of build runs of sizable footprint. I would like to be able to say that no matter how old the builds are to only keep the last X sets of build results.

{panel}
Global Configuration
What should be expired? Artifacts
Expiry period 7 days
Minimum builds to keep 5
Labels to keep keep-logs keep-artifacts
{panel}

No I could play around with the days but this is bound not to hold up due to bursts of activity for the project. I want to be able to say "Keep at most the last 10 builds" regardless of age...
fields.summary: At most keep X number of builds for Build Expiry

fields.description:
Hello

At the moment I am creating test plans for one of our projects. However, I'm seen that the whole thing is going to become very difficult to manage very soon. For this project (and for a good number of other projects) we have a number of platforms to test, each with a number of C and Fortran compilers (vendors and versions), compilation options (static,shared) and environment options (libraries present or present, etc). 

I see that for a single project the number of tests could already be close to 50, then multiply by 10-15. Not all are that complex but some are indeed so we could easily end with several hundreds of test plans. At the moment I am creating them with the "clone" feature (it would be good it is also initially copied project name and key, btw, because these tend to be variations of the cloned ones) but the whole thing is starting to get difficult to manage. I see two issues:

1. In the Project screen we will just have a quite long flat list, not every easy to spot things. I'm trying to use the names with some discipline so that things are sorted right, but this is not very nice.

2. If (when) I have to modify a value in the plans, I will have to re-do the change in tens of other similar plans. Very labor intensive and error prone.

So, wouldn't it be nice to organize the plans in a tree so that:

1. You can show/hide or open/close branches so that you can just ignore those that are building OK. It could give a nice visual hint to discover if a problem happens per architecture, os, compiler or compilation options.

2. Configuration (requirements, settings, etc) could be inherited from the parent plan in the tree. A child should be able to override any parameter but by default would have the same settings as the parent.

I believe that this would make the whole thing manageable. Do you have any other ideas?
fields.summary: Better way of handling large number of plans: Plan tree, with configuration inheritance?

fields.description:
We base our build setup heavily on Maven 2 / 3, and for release builds make use of it's inbuilt feature for doing that, which we are very happy with, and would like to stick with.

What would be very useful is some way to drive this from the Bamboo UI.  We have looked at the release plugin that's now available for Bamboo, but it duplicates much of what Maven gives us, without integrating with Maven very well, plus its tight integration with JIRA for versioning is not suitable for how we structure our projects.

Given Bamboo has excellent Maven2 integration elsewhere it would be great to have a feature which integrates the two nicely here, and it doesn't feel like it would be a massive piece of work.  Other apps like Hudson / Continuum have something similar, so would be good for Bamboo to tick that box too.

In terms of what it would need to do I'd suggest this would be the minimum:
- No duplicate plan - just a tab on the existing Maven 2 based plan
- Maven builder settings etc just taken from the main plan
- Text boxes to provide the username / password for the SCM actions (username defaulted from logged in user, naturally)
- Text box to provide the release version, though that could be left blank to let Maven default it as usual
- Then just run mvn release:prepare release:perform (or in 2 calls if that makes the UI nicer...)
fields.summary: Maven 2 / 3 Release Plugin integration
Create UT for plan requirements import/export

fields.description:
When we run the Confluence release process, the source which is checked out for a later job is not available until an earlier job runs.

The Bamboo plan refuses to run if any job in the plan cannot check out its source. It would be good if this restriction was only applied at the stage level, so you only verified the availability of the source code for each enabled job in the first stage.

Our current workaround is quite painful: we enable and disable the jobs in three sets. The first set creates the distribution tag, the second set requires the distribution tag in order to run. The third set contains our optional post-release steps. Enabling and disabling jobs requires a lot of clicks, so this process takes a lot longer than necessary.
fields.summary: Inability to check out source for a single job should not prevent plan from starting

Whilst some of our front end code accomodates this, some of it doesn't (e.g. select/show/hide stuff)

I was originally going to convert everything over to a string when i put it on the stack, but I'm not sure how many assumptions I can make (are they all supposed to be strings, what if the front end really does want an array)

fields.description:
Currently when you upgrade Bamboo from 3.0 to 3.1 you might see the following stacktrace in your logs: https://paste.atlassian.com/view/2745
The stacktrace is completely harmless and not representative of a big error. It only appears when your logger level is set so that you see INFO messages.

The stacktrace appears because of a failed lookup attempt for a Trusted Application which existed with the older implementation (the TA plugin implementation) but cannot be found with the new way (the database-backed TA implementation). To fix this problem we can write an upgrade task to migrate the old TA data over.

fields.description:
When migrating from Builds to Plans, we did not convert the global reports of Clover plugin. They operate on Plan metadata, but Clover metadata is only available at Job level.
Clover plugin should be extended by two plugin points: one to aggregate Clover metadata after chain finishes and one to index that metadata in Lucene.
fields.summary: Global Clover reports do not work

fields.description:
Currently the Command Builder requires a command to be provided when the Builder is created. 

This forces the admin to create multiple builders if multiple jobs in a plan use different commands.

It would be very useful if the command could be defined directly in the Plan/Job. It would make the configuration less complex and faster.
fields.summary: Command Builder should allow the command definition at the Plan UI

fields.description:
Please see attached screen shot.

If "Command" is chosen, the list box comment ask for a script. For sure, the command can be a script as well, but the comment should be valuing this option by using an example that is really a command.

Also, it is not clear if the command can have arguments or not. If so, please add arguments to the example as well.

Finally, instead of "Path" the text box should be labeled with "Command and Arguments" and have an example (maybe the example from the list box can be moved to the text box?.)

fields.description:
From marek
{noformat}
There is a bug when process service prepares environment for process.

It takes Map<String, String> with environment and translates it into String[] with environment.
The problem is when value contains space (quite usual setup)

So when have entry in the map
"MVN_OPTS", "-Xmx512m -XX:MaxPermSize:256m"

As a result we got
"MVN_OPTS=-Xmx512m -XX:MaxPermSize:256m"

which is wrong - it has to be:

"MVN_OPTS=\"-Xmx512m -XX:MaxPermSize:256m\""

Otherwise we got unrecognized option for java, as this is already new process parameter - so task fails.

{noformat}
fields.summary: ExternalProcess should quote environment variable value.

fields.description:
Raised from BSP-4321 .
When connectivity is lost between the agent and the broker or Bamboo HTTP server, the agents crash. This causes problems for clients using large amounts agents.
Agents don't really need to crash for reasons that cannot be locally resolved, like java.net.ConnectException . Instead, they should just try to restart (maybe even indefinitely).
fields.summary: Agents don't reconnect to the broker after connectivity is lost

It would be nice to be able to pass in a bamboo variable into the Location property when creating or editing an Artifact Definition.  Then the customer does not have to worry about editing all their definitions and can control with a variable.

I don't know if this is a bug or feature request since I reported the variables passing into Environment Variables in the Builder.

fields.description:
I have a build plan in which I have selected "Bamboo should invoke MSTest directly" 
I have the following parameters: 
Run Config: common\Test\TestSettingsCodeCoverage.testsettings
Container: common\Test\bin\x86\Debug\TestCommon.dll

I can invoke MSTest.exe command line successfully with these parameters, but when I run it as a part of the Bamboo build, it truncates my input for Container (strips off the container .dll) and aborts. I get the following error: 

simple	22-Feb-2011 14:52:48	Build process for 'Work Assignment - Work Assignment - Default Job' returned with return code = 0
command	22-Feb-2011 14:52:48	Substituting variable: ${bamboo.build.working.directory} with D:\bamboo\1\xml-data\build-dir\WORKASSIGNMENT-TRUNK-JOB1
build	22-Feb-2011 14:52:49	Microsoft (R) Test Execution Command Line Tool Version 10.0.30319.1
build	22-Feb-2011 14:52:49	Copyright (c) Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.
build	22-Feb-2011 14:52:49	    
build	22-Feb-2011 14:52:49	File name "D:\bamboo\1\xml-data\build-dir\WORKASSIGNMENT-TRUNK-JOB1\trunk\common\Test\bin\x86\Debug\" is invalid.
build	22-Feb-2011 14:52:49	For switch syntax, type "MSTest /help"

Neither the bamboo agent logs, nor the bamboo server logs provide any useful errors or messages.
